Award.AwardTitle: Implementation Project: Fisk University STEM Transformation via Strategies for Accelerated Mathematics Confidence, Deeper Learning, and Course-embedded Authentic Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project at Fisk University, a Historically Black University, builds on lessons learned from a planning grant. The overall goal of the project is to enhance undergraduate student interest, retention, learning success, and pursuit of post-graduation training or careers in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) areas. Three main strategies were selected to overcome barriers to student success: innovation in developmental and early mathematics courses to achieve accelerated acquisition of STEM pre-requisite skills; introduction of Supplementary Instruction in all Gatekeeper STEM courses to achieve deeper learning and student retention; and introduction of course-embedded research in two required courses in each Natural Science discipline, and in one mathematics and computer science course, to enhance STEM interest, critical thinking and concept mastery.

The project will collect data concerning the suitability of evidence-based practices successful in research-based universities for implementation in small liberal arts colleges focused on increasing minority student access to STEM careers. Additionally, accelerated mathematics confidence and a deeper understanding of fundamental concepts for application in novel settings will facilitate academic success of students at Fisk University as STEM majors and in seeking STEM careers.

This project has the potential for becoming a model for STEM education at small liberal arts institutions. The project is likely to have an impact on STEM education, student learning, and faculty practice.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Implementation Project at Fisk University was proposed in response to an understanding of the needs of incoming students in order to persist in STEM ( science, technology, engineering, and mathematics)  disciplines and graduate with a STEM undergraduate degree as a prelude to post-graduate training or a career that contributes to society using the tools of discovery or leadership in STEM. Those needs included:  developing a greater confidence in mathematics to prepare for next-step courses in the sciences ; engaging students in the application of course content to solve new and more challenging problems using a structured, peer-led program referred to as Supplementary Instruction;  increasing faculty research capacity at Fisk University so that undergraduate students in the sciences could 'behave as a scientist' by engaging in faculty-mentored research projects or in course-associated authentic research; and engaging in faculty development activities that fostered  teaching strategies that more fully engaged students, referred to as 'student-centered pedagogies'.  The Implementation Award at Fisk University transformed the scientific teaching and research culture on this campus. Students advanced through so-called 'gatekeeper' courses with increased academic performance due to innovations in the Developmental Mathematics course and embracing Supplementary Instruction in General Chemistry- often a major barrier to students continuing in STEM majors. Newly hired  faculty engaged students in their research while at the same time inspiring interdisciplinary collaborations with faculty on campus. Faculty interest in innovating their teaching strategies led to the development of a Center for Teaching and Learning at Fisk University. Eight courses in undergraduate sciences were modified to infuse authentic research into course-associated laboratories, and more courses are continuing to be modified. Both faculty and students affirm that course-associated laboratories that infuse authentic research are more enjoyable as well as more educational. These course-associated experiences have led to students changing their initial career plans and applying to and successfully entering PhD programs in the sciences after graduating from Fisk University.Additional faculty recruitment at Fisk University has resulted in young faculty who inspire students as well as support and inspire interdisciplinary research and course development among the STEM disciplines, leading to two new majors at Fisk,  Biochemistry and Molecular Biology and Data Science , with the ongoing development of a new major in Bioiinformatics - all disciplines with expanding need and career opportunities in our society. Altogether, the activities and outcomes of this Fisk University Implementation Project have set the stage to increase the diversity among the STEM workforce in discovery, teaching the next generation of talent, and in national leadership to assure that science continues to serve rather than threaten our society.
